Text.Value: Coward. Stand and fight me!
'So he has spoken'? What 'he' are you talking about?
Because that would be senseless.
Fate has not declared mine injury. Therefore, it shall not occur.
We have met and I know thy face.
You feel familiar. Do I know you?

EditorData.AnimationTags: CDavis: Jergal climbing out of his tomb and standing up before the player.
EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Jergal climbing out of his tomb and standing up before the player

Text.Value: Now I have a question for thee: what is the worth of a single mortal's life?
I don't owe you answers.
Some do, yes.
Quite the question. What's the reason for it?
See what thou hast seen. Know what thou knowest.
Little spooked by the crawling out of the tomb bit. What are you?
Wilt thou answer my question?
What an imbalance.
That depends on a person's deeds.
In my experience, that depends on what the mortal looks like.
That depends on the virtue of the life that is lived.
Can you not be harmed? What magic is this?
I am sure thou believest as such.
Some mortals live much longer than others. I can't compare them.
Each life is of infinite value and merits sacrificing everything for.
Leave.
You feel familiar. Do I know you?
Hast thou finished?
And thus balance is achieved. If all are at war, none can win.
An arbiter of certain matters. But that is not important now.
At this particular junction, perhaps that is not so far from the truth.
A peaceful undead. Interesting. Why aren't you attacking me?
I am not the same as those thou hast slain, if that is what thou askest.
Depends on the mortal.
What manner of undead are you to ask such a question?
Thou walk with death, child of Kelemvor. That is enough for an understanding between us.
Thou walk with death, child of Myrkul. That is enough for an understanding between us.
A life is only valuable in service to Vlaakith.
Mortals live to die. To be slaughtered.
I am curious by what standards thou shalt judge.
Curiosity. Nothing more.
Attack.
Life's only value is as currency. Doesn't matter to me otherwise.
A life is worth only as much as the legends remember it.
Life only has value where Lolth decrees it.
In death, that is so.
Mortal lives are not 'single'. They are part of a greater whole - a path to enlightenment.
Lower your weapon and apologise.
So he has spoken, and so thou standest before me. Right as always.
So I ask again: what is the worth of a single mortal life?
Neither thy outburst nor thy apology is relevant.
Very well. I am satisfied.
We will see each other again at the proper time and place. Farewell.
Dull your weapons as you wish.
Yes, but I imagine it is not the way thee believe.
Ah, but thou lack a voice to speak. No matter. I have seen enough.
It is mortality just the same.
What a curious way to awaken.
We will see each other again at the proper time and place. Farewell.
The only life that matters is mine.
Few strive for such balance. Fewer still achieve it.
That is true, but matters not.
A life and how it is lived are different equations.
Mine seems worth little, as my blood calls me to harm others.
Yes. Ask away.
No one life is worth more than any other. We are all equal.
To some, it is the only currency.

Synopsis: After the party has slain a group of undead scholars, the judge of death--Jergal--climbs out of his sarcophagus to greet them. He has been locked inside for years by the god Helm to atone for his part in raising the Dead Three, wicked gods who are now plotting to conquer the realms. Jergal is emotionless and excessively formal, both resigned to his fate and that of others. He is here to assist the party because that is his divine oath, not out of any true desire to act. Players can attempt to goad or attack him, but to minimal effect, as he is functionally immortal. His only goal was to see their faces, so he can find them at camp later to offer further assistance.
